problems.question: When a non-metal burns in oxygen, what kind of oxide does it typically form?
problems.hint: Non-metal oxides tend to behave like acids in water.
problems.detailed: Non-metals reacting with oxygen generally form oxides which are acidic in nature. For example, \(\ce{C + O2 -> CO2}\), and \(\ce{CO2 + H2O -> H2CO3}\). So the correct answer is an acidic oxide.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Carbon reacts with oxygen to form what product under excess oxygen?
problems.hint: In full combustion, carbon combines fully with oxygen.
problems.detailed: In excess oxygen, carbon oxidizes fully to carbon dioxide: \(\ce{C + O2 -> CO2}\). So the product is \(\ce{CO2}\).
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Which reaction shows a non-metal displacing another from its salt solution?
problems.hint: Only more reactive non-metal can displace a less reactive one from compounds.
problems.detailed: Chlorine is more reactive than bromine, so \(\ce{Cl2}\) can displace bromine from \(\ce{NaBr}\): \(\ce{Cl2 + 2NaBr -> 2NaCl + Br2}\). Hence option A is correct.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: Non-metals are generally unable to displace hydrogen from dilute acids. Which of these is a correct consequence?
options: They show no reaction with dilute acids
problems.hint: Non-metals do not donate electrons to hydrogen ions.
problems.detailed: Non-metals are electron acceptors and cannot reduce \(\ce{H+}\) ions to hydrogen gas. Thus they do not displace hydrogen in dilute acid and show no reaction. So option C is correct.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov

problems.question: What kind of hydrides do non-metals form when reacting with hydrogen?
problems.hint: Non-metals share electrons rather than transfer when bonding with hydrogen.
problems.detailed: Non-metals form covalent hydrides by sharing electrons with hydrogen, e.g. \(\ce{NH3}\) or \(\ce{HCl}\). They do not form ionic hydrides in most normal cases. Option C is correct.
problems.author: Cabir Abassov
